author: pcAdminPNG
title: Japan funds new waste management facility
text:
THE JAPANESE government has donated a new waste management facility and X-ray machine to Kupiano Hospital in the Abau District of Central Province.
The handover ceremony was officiated by the Japanese Ambassador to Papua New Guinea, H.E Watanabe Nobuyuki, on Tuesday 2nd October 2024.
The waste management facility, known as the “Waste-Zone Project,” is the first of its kind in Papua New Guinea and aims to improve infection prevention and control practices at health facilities.
The project includes the installation of incinerators, sinks, water pumps, and other essential waste management equipment.
Ambassador Watanabe highlighted the importance of proper waste management in healthcare settings and emphasised Japan’s commitment to supporting the health sector in Papua New Guinea.
He noted that the new facility would help to protect both patients and healthcare workers from infections and maintain a clean and safe environment.
In addition to the waste management facility, the Japanese government also donated a new X-ray machine to Kupiano Hospital.
This equipment will greatly enhance the hospital’s diagnostic capabilities and improve patient care.
The projects were funded by the Japanese government as part of its efforts to strengthen the health system in Papua New Guinea and mitigate the impact of COVID-19.
The total cost of the projects is over US$2.7 million (K10.6m).
The handover ceremony was attended by representatives from the Central Provincial Health Authority, the Department of Health, and the World Health Organisation.
The participating dignitaries expressed their gratitude to the Japanese government for its generous support and emphasised the importance of these projects in improving healthcare services in the Central Province.
